awd_titl_txt: RUI: Carbon-carbon single bond activation as a route to new organic transformations
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Jeffrey B. Johnson of the Department of Chemistry at Hope College is developing new methods for the efficient production of organic compounds through the activation of carbon-carbon bonds. Carbon-carbon bonds are extremely common, making up the framework of molecules derived from living things as well as many polymers and other important materials. Despite their prevalence, there are few reaction conditions known that can selectively break these bonds. Professor Johnson and his group of undergraduate collaborators are working to understand the processes by which these few known reactions occur.  They are using this information to develop new methods to activate and transform carbon-carbon bonds. Successful realization of these goals promises more efficient synthetic routes to complex molecules, including new compounds that can be examined for biological activity as potential pharmaceutical agents. Undergraduate students strengthen their personal scientific preparation through participation in this project.  In turn, these undergraduates serve as Upward Bound mentors, assisting at-risk high school students prepare for college and potential futures in STEM fields.  

Professor Jeffrey B. Johnson is developing new reactions for the transition metal-catalyzed activation and functionalization of carbon-carbon single bonds. Undergraduate collaborators are carrying out the mechanistic investigation of the rhodium-catalyzed decarbonylation of 2-pyridylbenzophenones, determining energy barriers and identifying reaction intermediates. As Lewis basic directing groups are generally required for selective carbon-carbon bond activation, efforts focus on the use of readily removed or manipulated directing groups for the identification of conditions that allow the use of a broad range of ketones and carboxylic acid derivatives. The activation of these substrates, followed by coupling with readily available pi systems or organometallics, promises rapid access to a wide range of complex molecules with potential biological activity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Carbon-carbon single bonds make up the structural backbone of organic molecules--compounds as varied as plastics, plant matter or pharmaceuticals--and are unreactive in the vast majority of reaction conditions. But in this project funded by the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation, Professor Jeffrey B. Johnson of the Department of Chemistry at Hope College and his group of undergraduate researchers have pursued ways in which these bonds can be broken. The group has developed new methods for creating useful new molecules while also pursuing studies that have provided insight into how these rare chemical reactions work. Research during this grant period has led to 2 papers to date, as well as a number of manuscripts in various stages of preparation. In addition, 38 students received training in the pursuit of this project, and have obtained results that will undoubtedly lead into numerous new research avenues.

The primary impact of this project has been the training of undergraduate researchers, who have bene responsible for carrying out all facets of the program. Nearly 40 students contributed to projects supported by this award, developing both technical skills specific to the project and general skills that contribute to success in any field. These generally applicable skills, including the ability to organic and analyze complex data, to communicate their findings, to think critically, and to develop research strategies, will prepare these students for any number of future careers. In addition to undergraduate students, this award also supported the training of three graduate students, allowing them to mentor a small group of students at an undergraduate institution. This provided these graduate students with experience not available at their home research institutions and giving them a sense of a potential career in small college academics.

Students presented widely on their work, giving over 70 presentations at local, regional and national meetings. Of the 38 students receiving training under this award, 19 have graduated from college, proceeding on to medical school, graduate school, law school, and into chemical industry. Regardless of their specific role, these students have been equipped with numerous skills and extensive scientific literacy that will benefit them for years to come.

Beyond the fundamental laboratory research, aspects of this project influenced the general education curriculum at Hope College, as well as upper level biology courses. The project also supported a collaboration with the Hope College Upward Bound Program, a program that assists at-risk high school students prepare for college. Undergraduate student researchers worked with these students on a routine basis, preparing hands-on experiential activities to promote engagement with and enthusiasm for science. Over 75% of Upward Bound students have continued on to post-secondary education, with many pursuing scientific programs, ultimately serving to improve diversity within STEM fields.
